block.p: Emissions Already Shaping World Climate, Panel Says The earth's climate and ecosystems are already being shaped by greenhouse gases, the world's leading scientific panel on climate change said. While limits on emissions could lower long-term risks, it said, vulnerable regions must adjust promptly to shifting weather patterns and coastal hazards.

Britons Describe Iran Captivity Six of the 15 British marines and sailors who arrived home after being held in Iran said days of psychological pressure extracted ''confessions'' from some of the captives that they strayed into Iranian waters. They said they were separated, put in pajamas and placed in cells.

Zambia to Exhaust U.N. Rations Within weeks, rations provided by the United Nations World Food Program will run out for 500,000 Zambian paupers, including thousands of people wasted by AIDS who are being treated with American-financed drugs that make them hungrier as they grow healthier.

Chlorine Truck Bomb in Iraq A suicide truck bomb loaded with chlorine gas exploded in Ramadi, killing as many as 30 people, many of them children, a security official said. The blast was at least the sixth chlorine bomb detonated in Anbar Province since late January.

Gandhi Heir Fights for Base Rahul Gandhi, the 36-year-old heir apparent to India's ruling political dynasty, is facing his first test of political mettle: whether he can save his Congress Party from becoming irrelevant in Uttar Pradesh, India's most populous state and the Nehru-Gandhi family's home base.

Top Aide to Gonzales Announces Resignation A top aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, Monica Goodling, resigned, another casualty of the political storm that has rocked the Justice Department since the firings of eight United States attorneys. A1

Charity Act Raises Questions One of Japan's richest real estate developers, Genshiro Kawamoto, is making good on a plan to open eight houses he owns in one of Honolulu's most exclusive communities to poor families of Native Hawaiian descent. But while his act of charity has made headlines around the world, it has also raised plenty of questions.

A Faster 'Road Home'? Louisiana homeowners may get faster access to rebuilding grants after a surprise ruling from Washington that is forcing the state to change its slow-moving $7.5 billion ''Road Home'' program to repair houses damaged or destroyed by the 2005 hurricanes.
Many Unhappy With School Law As the president and some Democrats push to renew the No Child Left Behind law, discontent with it in many states is threatening to undermine the effort in both parties.

California Psychiatrist Arrested A prominent California child psychiatrist who had treated four generations of troubled youth and preached sex education on public television was arrested, accused of sexually abusing three of his charges. A8
Orders to Stop Sale of Drug The Food and Drug Administration ordered drug companies to stop selling anti-nausea suppositories containing a drug that they said does not work when used in that form.

Fourth Man Arrested In String of Bank Robberies A fourth man was arrested in connection with a string of recent bank robberies in New Jersey, one day after an F.B.I. agent was killed, apparently by another agent, while following the suspects, the authorities said. The charges filed against three of the men may be amended to include murder, officials said. B1

Opposition Rule Not So Bad The Democratic majority in Washington has created a peculiar reality: many moderate Republicans from swing districts in the Northeast are finding that life under Democratic rule has its advantages. A1

Trade Dispute with China After months of prodding China to crack down on pirated copies of American movies, music and software, the Bush administration appears ready to escalate the dispute into a formal complaint.
A Role In Cutting Emissions Automakers and their Washington trade group are now saying they want an active role in the movement to reduce damage that vehicles do to the environment. C1
Job Growth Rises The job market showed little sign of losing its vigor in March as wages climbed and job growth rose by the largest amount so far this year, the Labor Department reported.
Elizabeth Reilley A librarian who amassed a major collection of rare books on landscape design, she was 99.
Editorials: The real fumble in Damascus; breast cancer screening; a chance to be heard; warriors home in Washington.
Bridge B16 TV Listings B17 Crosswrod B15 Weather C8
